item.title: China Gives Death Sentence to Canadian Charged With Making Ketamine
item.description: A Chinese court imposed the death penalty on a Canadian citizen charged with producing illicit drugs, in a case that could further strain already frayed ties between Beijing and Ottawa.

item.title: Covid Derails Latin America's Bid for Middle-Class Prosperity
item.description: The region faces a 9.4% GDP decline this year, the worst downfall on record, and will likely lag other emerging markets in any recovery. It’s a major blow for millions who were making the long climb out of poverty.

item.title: U.S.-South Korea Military Exercises Stay Digital, as North's Threat Grows
item.description: The U.S. and South Korea plan to start their third major combined military exercise using computer simulations as early as next week, two years after President Trump ordered field drills be scaled back.

item.title: Beirut Explosion Leads to Growing Anger as Lebanon Searches for Victims
item.description: Lebanese authorities scrambled to clear the rubble left from this week’s massive explosion and search for victims, as the government continued its investigation into the causes of a blast that killed at least 137 people and injured thousands.

item.title: Pope Francis Names Six Women to Senior Vatican Positions
item.description: Pope Francis named six women to the body that oversees Vatican finances, making them the most senior female officials ever to serve at the Vatican.

item.title: Hong Kong Is Losing Its Charm for Expats as China Tightens the Screws
item.description: The city’s expatriate community is shrinking, as new restrictions by China on speech and political activities and a tumultuous year of protests have diminished the allure of living and working in the Asian financial hub.
